No gravity-particle has been discovered (graviton?). But there are theories=
 about gravity being a particle, or a bend in space-time, or a wave, or a l=
ot of things.=C2=A0 Science is still grappling with this.


--- On Wed, 6/2=
/10, Frank Sumption <purplealiengirl@...> wrote:

From: Frank Sumptio=
n <purplealiengirl@...>
Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Re: Tesing-testing
To:=
 EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wednesday, June 2, 2010, 9:55 AM







=C2=
=A0



  


    
      
      
      
I thought gravity was a particle.
=C2=
=A0
=C2=A0F-S

On Wed, Jun 2, 2010 at 10:45 AM, Zack Widup <w9sz.zack@gmail=
. com> wrote:


=C2=A0 




Yes; if it happened now it would be visible 500=
 years from now. If it happened 500 years ago, it would be visible now.
=C2=
=A0
However, there are people including Greg Hodowanec who have collected s=
ome evidence that gravity waves are near instantaneous, and that if a super=
nova occurred now, it could be detected now. Still, we wouldn't SEE it for =
500 years. And=C2=A0the equipment=C2=A0described by Hodowanec (which I've b=
uilt)=C2=A0can't tell us WHERE the supernova occurred, just the fact it did=
.


Zack


=C2=A0
On Wed, Jun 2, 2010 at 10:10 AM, draiga1 <blackwing@cox. =
net> wrote:


=C2=A0 



Fiona,

Sorry to butt in, but I'm curious. If this=
 is happening 500 Light Years away from us, doesn't that mean it will be vi=
sible to us in 500 years? I know that there is a delay with sound such as t=
hunder, then the delay before an individual hears it depending on how far t=
hey are from where the sound originated. Wouldn't it be the same with light=
?


~Draiga
